label: The Urban Observatory Core Vocabulary
comment: A vocabulary for linked sensor networks and observations
dc:description: The Urban Observatory vocabulary provides a consistent means of describing sensors and monitoring networks, and their relationship to infrastructure systems.
dc:rights: Copyright © 2020 Newcastle University, University of Birmingham, University of Sheffield, University of Bristol, Cranfield University, University of Manchester

defines.label: collection
defines.comment: A collection of resources

defines.label: has member
defines.comment: A member of a collection
The fields of expertise to which an observation is relevent.

defines.label: unit
defines.comment: The unit of measure.

defines.label: recommended unit
defines.comment: Observations with this observed property are typically provided in this unit of measure. Other units may still be used but the alternative unit MUST be explicitly defined.

defines.label: meteorology
defines.comment: The scientific study of the atmosphere that focuses on weather processes and forecasting.

defines.label: atmospheric chemistry
defines.comment: Looks at the composition of planetary atmospheres and the reactions and interactions that drive these dynamic and diverse systems

defines.label: instrumental
defines.comment: Observations pertaining to the instruments (sensors/platforms) themselves. For example a weather station platform typically makes observations relevant to the discipline of Meteorology, however some sensors hosted on the weather station observe the health and status of the platform itself such as battery or signal strength readings. These observations would fall under the 'instrumental' discipline.

defines.label: ecology
defines.comment: The relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.

defines.label: energy
defines.comment: Relates to the production and supply of energy (electricity, gas, oil, etc) to households, businesses, industry and so on.

defines.label: hydrology
defines.comment: The branch of science concerned with the properties of the earth's water, and especially its movement in relation to land.

defines.label: transport
defines.comment: The movement of humans, animals and goods from one location to another.

defines.label: environmental acoustics
defines.comment: The domain of science and techniques related to the study of acoustic vibrations and concerning their production, propagation and effects in relation to the preservation of environment.

defines.label: air temperature
defines.comment: Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature. A dry-bulb temperature.

defines.label: dew point air temperature
defines.comment: Dew point air temperature is the temperature at which a parcel of air reaches saturation upon being cooled at constant pressure and specific humidity.

defines.label: grass surface temperature
defines.comment: Temperature of a grass covered surface. This observed property is commonly recorded at meterological observing sites.

defines.label: concrete surface temperature
defines.comment: Temperature of a concrete surface. This observed property is commonly recorded at meterological observing sites.

defines.label: soil temperature
defines.comment: Temperature of the soil. This observed property is commonly recorded at meterological observing sites, typically at multiple depths.

defines.label: relative humidity
defines.comment: Relative humidity (RH) is the ratio of the partial pressure of water vapour to the equilibrium vapour pressure of water at a given temperature. Relative humidity depends on temperature and the pressure of the system of interest.

defines.label: air pressure
defines.comment: Air pressure is the force per unit area which would be exerted when the moving gas molecules of which the air is composed strike a theoretical surface of any orientation. This is the pressure recorded at the elevation and altitude of the pressure sensor and has NOT been corrected to mean sea level.

defines.label: air pressure at mean sea level
defines.comment: Air pressure at sea level is the quantity often abbreviated as MSLP or PMSL. Air pressure is the force per unit area which would be exerted when the moving gas molecules of which the air is composed strike a theoretical surface of any orientation. 'Mean sea level' means the time mean of sea surface elevation at a given location over an arbitrary period sufficient to eliminate the tidal signals.

defines.label: wind speed
defines.comment: Speed is the magnitude of velocity. Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.) The wind speed is the magnitude of the wind velocity.

defines.label: wind speed
defines.comment: Speed is the magnitude of velocity. Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.) The wind speed is the magnitude of the wind velocity. A gust is a sudden brief period of high wind speed. In an observed timeseries of wind speed, the gust wind speed can be indicated by a maximum for the time-interval.

defines.label: wind direction
defines.comment: Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. Given as the direction the wind has come FROM. I.e. 90° would represent an easterly wind direction from east to west.

defines.label: wind gust direction
defines.comment: Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. Given as the direction the wind has come FROM. I.e. 90° would represent an easterly wind direction from east to west. Typically given in combination with a uo:WindGustSpeed observation, with the uo:WindGustDirection indicating the direction the maximum wind speeds came from.

defines.label: precipitation depth
defines.comment: An indication of the average depth of precipitation. Provided over a specified time window. Tipping bucket rain gauges typically convert precipitation volume into a depth based on the area of the gauge.

defines.label: precipitation rate
defines.comment: Indicates how heavy the precipitation is as an expected depth of precipitaton per fixed time frame, e.g. millimetres per hour.

defines.label: solar radiation
defines.comment: Solar radiation is the power per unit area received from the Sun in the form of electromagnetic radiation as reported in the wavelength range of the measuring instrument. A measure of the total incoming (direct and diffuse) solar radiation. Typically measured with a pyranometer.

defines.label: lightning count
defines.comment: The number of lightning counts detected over a time period. Observations of lighting counts MUST include a phenomenonTime object detailing the start and end of this time period.

defines.label: lightning distance
defines.comment: The distance from the sensor to the observed lightning strike.

defines.label: vapour pressure
defines.comment: The pressure exerted by a vapour in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed phases (solid or liquid) at a given temperature in a closed system.

defines.label: battery voltage
defines.comment: The voltage reading of a battery.

defines.label: battery remaining
defines.comment: The percentage of battery remaining.

defines.label: LAeq
defines.comment: A-weighted equivalent continuous sound level in decibels measured over a stated period of time. A-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in an effort to account for the relative loudness perceived by the human ear, which is less sensitive to low audio frequencies. This means that A-weighted measurements correlate well with the perceived loudness at low sound levels.

defines.label: LAFmax
defines.comment: The maximum noise level with A-weighted frequency response and Fast time constant. A-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in an effort to account for the relative loudness perceived by the human ear, which is less sensitive to low audio frequencies. This means that A-weighted measurements correlate well with the perceived loudness at low sound levels. 'Fast time constant' means that only audio signals with a rise and decay time of up to 125 ms are considered.

defines.label: LA10
defines.comment: A-weighted, sound level exceeded for 10% of the measurement period. A-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in an effort to account for the relative loudness perceived by the human ear, which is less sensitive to low audio frequencies. This means that A-weighted measurements correlate well with the perceived loudness at low sound levels. LA10 is extensively used for rating traffic noise

defines.label: LA50
defines.comment: A-weighted, sound level exceeded for 50% of the measurement period. A-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in an effort to account for the relative loudness perceived by the human ear, which is less sensitive to low audio frequencies. This means that A-weighted measurements correlate well with the perceived loudness at low sound levels.

defines.label: LA90
defines.comment: A-weighted, sound level exceeded for 90% of the measurement period. A-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in an effort to account for the relative loudness perceived by the human ear, which is less sensitive to low audio frequencies. This means that A-weighted measurements correlate well with the perceived loudness at low sound levels. LA90 is extensively used for rating background noise

defines.label: LCeq
defines.comment: C-weighted equivalent continuous sound level in decibels measured over a stated period of time. C-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in order to describe the response of the human ear to high noise levels. C-weighted measurements are commonly used to assess the effect of impulse noises on the human ear.

defines.label: LCFmax
defines.comment: The maximum noise level with C-weighted frequency response and Fast time constant. C-weighted equivalent continuous sound level in decibels measured over a stated period of time. C-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in order to describe the response of the human ear to high noise levels. C-weighted measurements are commonly used to assess the effect of impulse noises on the human ear. 'Fast time constant' means that only audio signals with a rise and decay time of up to 125 ms are considered.

defines.label: LC10
defines.comment: C-weighted, sound level exceeded for 10% of the measurement period. C-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in order to describe the response of the human ear to high noise levels. C-weighted measurements are commonly used to assess the effect of impulse noises on the human ear.

defines.label: LC50
defines.comment: C-weighted, sound level exceeded for 50% of the measurement period. C-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in order to describe the response of the human ear to high noise levels. C-weighted measurements are commonly used to assess the effect of impulse noises on the human ear.

defines.label: LC90
defines.comment: C-weighted, sound level exceeded for 90% of the measurement period. C-weighting is a filter applied to the sound pressure level in order to describe the response of the human ear to high noise levels. C-weighted measurements are commonly used to assess the effect of impulse noises on the human ear.

defines.label: tilt (north/south)
defines.comment: The degree to which a something (e.g. a sensor platform) has been tilted from an upright position in the north/south direction. North is positive, south is negative. When the thing being measured is directly upright the value is 0°. If it tilts towards the northerly direction the value will increase. If it tilts towards the southerly direction the value will decrease. For example, if the tilt of a metal post was being measured, and the post was knocked 10° from its upright direction towards the south the value would be -10°. If it was pushed back towards the north and fell completely flat on the ground the value would be +90°.

defines.label: tilt (west/east)
defines.comment: The degree to which a something (e.g. a sensor platform) has been tilted from an upright position in the west/east direction. West is positive, east is negative. When the thing being measured is directly upright the value is 0°. If it tilts towards the westerly direction the value will increase. If it tilts towards the easterly direction the value will decrease. For example, if the tilt of a metal post was being measured, and the post was knocked 10° from its upright direction towards the east the value would be -10°. If it was pushed back towards the west and fell completely flat on the ground the value would be +90°.

defines.label: degree celsius
defines.comment: Celsius, also known as centigrade, is a scale and unit of measurement for temperature. It can refer to a specific temperature on the Celsius scale as well as a unit to indicate a temperature interval, a difference between two temperatures or an uncertainty. This definition fixes the magnitude of both the degree Celsius and the kelvin as precisely 1 part in 273.16 (approximately 0.00366) of the difference between absolute zero and the triple point of water. Thus, it sets the magnitude of one degree Celsius and that of one kelvin as exactly the same. Additionally, it establishes the difference between the two scales' null points as being precisely 273.15°C.

defines.label: kelvin
defines.comment: The SI base unit of temperature, previously called the degree Kelvin. One kelvin represents the same temperature difference as one degree Celsius. In 1967 the General Conference on Weights and Measures defined the temperature of the triple point of water (the temperature at which water exists simultaneously in the gaseous, liquid, and solid states) to be exactly 273.16 kelvins. Since this temperature is also equal to 0.01 u00b0C, the temperature in kelvins is always equal to 273.15 plus the temperature in degrees Celsius. The kelvin equals exactly 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit. The unit is named for the British mathematician and physicist William Thomson (1824-1907), later known as Lord Kelvin after he was named Baron Kelvin of Largs.

defines.label: percent
defines.comment: 'Percent' is a unit for 'Dimensionless Ratio' expressed as %.

defines.label: hectopascal
defines.comment: Hectopascal is a unit of pressure. 1 Pa is approximately the pressure exerted by a 10 g mass resting on a 1 cm squared area. 1013 hPa = 1 atm. There are 100 pascals in 1 hectopascal.

defines.label: metre per second
defines.comment: Metre per second is an SI derived unit of both speed (scalar) and velocity (vector quantity which specifies both magnitude and a specific direction), defined by distance in metres divided by time in seconds.

defines.label: degree
defines.comment: A degree (in full, a degree of arc, arc degree, or arcdegree), usually denoted by ∘ (the degree symbol), is a measurement of plane angle, representing 1/360 of a full rotation; one degree is equivalent to 2π/360rad, 0.017453rad. It is not an SI unit, as the SI unit for angles is radian, but is an accepted SI unit.

defines.label: millimetre
defines.comment: Unit of distance. Equal to one thousandth of a metre, which is the SI base unit of length.

defines.label: millimetre per hour
defines.comment: A measure of speed. Also commonly used for the observable property uo:PrecipitationRate as a depth of rainfall per hour.

defines.label: kilometre per hour
defines.comment: Kilometer per Hour is a C.G.S System unit for 'Linear Velocity'.

defines.label: kilometre
defines.comment: A common metric unit of length or distance. One kilometer equals exactly 1000 meters, about 0.621 371 19 mile, 1093.6133 yards, or 3280.8399 feet. Oddly, higher multiples of the meter are rarely used; even the distances to the farthest galaxies are usually measured in kilometers.

defines.label: kilopascal
defines.comment: Kilopascal is a unit of pressure. 1 kPa is approximately the pressure exerted by a 10-g mass resting on a 1-cm2 area. 101.3 kPa = 1 atm. There are 1,000 pascals in 1 kilopascal.

defines.label: count
defines.comment: A dimensionless number indicating a count of something.

defines.label: watt per square metre
defines.comment: A unit of irradiance defined as the power received per area. This is a unit in the category of Energy flux. It is also known as watts per square meter, watt per square metre, watts per square metre, watt/square meter, watt/square metre. This unit is commonly used in the SI unit system. This unit is the standard SI unit in this category.

defines.label: parts per million
defines.comment: Dimensionless unit for concentration.

defines.label: parts per billion
defines.comment: Dimensionless unit for concentration.

defines.label: microgram per cubic metre
defines.comment: Unit of density, defined by mass in micrograms divided by volume in cubic metres. Commonly used for National Air Quality Objectives.

defines.label: decibel
defines.comment: A customary logarithmic measure most commonly used (in various ways) for measuring sound.The beginning of the scale, 0 decibels, can be set in different ways, depending on exactly the aspect of sound being measured. For sound intensity (the power of the sound waves per unit of area) 0 decibel is equal to 1 picowatts per metre squared. This corresponds approximately to the faintest sound that can be detected by a person who has good hearing. For sound pressure (the pressure exerted by the sound waves) 0 decibels equals 20 micropascals RMS, and for sound power 0 decibels sometimes equals 1 picowatt. In all cases, one decibel equals ≈ 0.115129 neper.

defines.label: volt
defines.comment: Volt is the SI unit of electric potential. Electric potential is defined as the amount of potential energy present per unit of charge. Electric potential is measured in volts, with one volt representing a potential of one joule per coulomb of charge. The volt also may be expressed with a variety of other units. For example, a volt is also equal to one watt per ampere (W/A) and one joule per ampere per second (J/A/s).
